2.text: I know it is so of a truth: but how should man be just with God?

3.text: If he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one of a thousand.

4.text: He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who has hardened himself against him, and has prospered?

5.text: Which removes the mountains, and they know not: which overturns them in his anger.

6.text: Which shakes the earth out of her place, and the pillars thereof tremble.

7.text: Which commands the sun, and it rises not; and seals up the stars.

8.text: Which alone spreads out the heavens, and treads on the waves of the sea.

9.text: Which makes Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.

10.text: Which does great things past finding out; yes, and wonders without number.

11.text: See, he goes by me, and I see him not: he passes on also, but I perceive him not.

12.text: Behold, he takes away, who can hinder him? who will say to him, What do you?

13.text: If God will not withdraw his anger, the proud helpers do stoop under him.

14.text: How much less shall I answer him, and choose out my words to reason with him?

15.text: Whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer, but I would make supplication to my judge.

16.text: If I had called, and he had answered me; yet would I not believe that he had listened to my voice.

17.text: For he breaks me with a tempest, and multiplies my wounds without cause.

18.text: He will not suffer me to take my breath, but fills me with bitterness.

19.text: If I speak of strength, see, he is strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time to plead?

20.text: If I justify myself, my own mouth shall condemn me: if I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse.

21.text: Though I were perfect, yet would I not know my soul: I would despise my life.

22.text: This is one thing, therefore I said it, He destroys the perfect and the wicked.

23.text: If the whip slay suddenly, he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.

24.text: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covers the faces of the judges thereof; if not, where, and who is he?

25.text: Now my days are swifter than a post: they flee away, they see no good.

26.text: They are passed away as the swift ships: as the eagle that hastens to the prey.

27.text: If I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my heaviness, and comfort myself:

28.text: I am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that you will not hold me innocent.

29.text: If I be wicked, why then labor I in vain?

30.text: If I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean;

31.text: Yet shall you plunge me in the ditch, and my own clothes shall abhor me.

32.text: For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, and we should come together in judgment.

33.text: Neither is there any judge between us, that might lay his hand on us both.

34.text: Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear terrify me:

35.text: Then would I speak, and not fear him; but it is not so with me.
